history.content:
I've taken Math 170 with Evans and EECS 127 with El Ghaoui.

Math 170 with Evans covered linear programs, the simplex algorithm for linear programs, some nonlinear programming, some convex analysis, some game theory (mostly fixed point theorems), some calculus of variations, and some control theory (using calculus of variations). The entire first half of the course was spent on linear programs and the simplex algorithm.

EECS 127 with El Ghaoui covered linear programs, quadratic programs, quadratically-constrained quadratic programs, and robust optimization.

They are very different courses. 170 tended to prove things more rigorously than 127 did, as you might expect from a math class. The topics covered in 170 are not as applied and therefore not as useful to most people. For most of machine learning, you would probably be better off with 127. 127 is definitely a higher workload class.

I found 170 to generally be a much more interesting class, since it proved things more rigorously and since it introduced new perspectives on optimization that I hadn't seen in classes like 189. I've also found 170 topics such as calculus of variations appearing in some mathematical machine learning papers.

Feel free to ask any questions in the followups.

children.subject:
I personally have not encountered calculus of variations many times in the papers that I have read. Most current machine learning papers do not contain much math at all, and the papers that do have some math often only use some relatively basic linear algebra and probability. It's possible that calculus of variations comes up more often in optimization and robotics (which are closely tied to machine learning), but those are not fields that I have personally read much into, so I'm not sure.

Even though you might not encounter calculus of variations directly in most machine learning papers today, it is a basic good-to-have tool of optimization, and I'm sure that learning them rigorously will give you a better understanding of mathematical optimization in general.

I haven't taken any physics classes at Berkeley, so maybe someone else would be able to discuss those specific physics classes you mentioned.

Here's an example of a paper where I encountered the Euler-Lagrange equation https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.04245.
Calculus of variations is very useful in controls and planning, as well as some other areas of robotics. It's one of the things I wish I had a stronger background on.

Hey I'm interested in calculus in variations and was wondering on how useful they are to machine learning. I am taking Physics 137A this semester and we've encountered things like the Hamiltonian, but not explored them rigorously. Also am interested in taking Physics 105 (Analytic Mechanics).

history.content: Has anyone taken math 170 here (Probably many of you have taken EECS 127)? What is the similarities and differences between the two courses? Which one is more challenging and more helpful for machine learning related theories?
history.subject: Math 170 vs EECS 127
